In a monoid $M$, an element $b \in M$ is called an inverse of a given element $a \in M$ if $ab = e = ba$. The element $b$, if it exists, is uniquely determined by $a$ and is denoted by $a^{-1}$.
The order of a group $G$, denoted as ord $G$, is defined as the number of elements in $G$ if $G$ is finite. If $G$ is infinite, its order is said to be infinite.
A field is a commutative division ring.
In any ring $R$, the zero ideal $\{0\}$ and the unit ideal $R$ are called trivial ideals. These are the only ideals if $R$ is a field.
A proper ideal $\mathfrak{p} \subsetneq R$ in a ring $R$ is called a prime ideal if for elements $a, b \in R$, $ab \in \mathfrak{p}$ implies $a \in \mathfrak{p}$ or $b \in \mathfrak{p}$.
A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called a system of generators of M if M = sum_{i in I} A x_i.
A purely inseparable extension is a field extension where the minimal polynomial of any element in the extension has a single root, which is repeated according to the degree of the polynomial.

A field $K$ is called algebraically closed if every nonconstant polynomial $f$ of $K[X]$ admits a zero in $K$, or in other words, if $f$ decomposes in $K[X]$ into a product of linear factors. This means that $f$ admits a product decomposition $f=c \prod_{i}\left(X-\alpha_{i}\right)$ with a constant $c \in K^{*}$ as well as zeros $\alpha_{i} \in K$.
Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension

The Galois group, or automorphism group, $\\[\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathbb{F}_q}(\mathbb{F}_{q'})\]$ of a finite field extension $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'} / \mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group of field automorphisms of $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'}\]$ that fix $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$. It is cyclic of order $n$, where $n$ is the degree of the extension.
A splitting field $L$ of a polynomial $f \\(in K[X]\\) with coefficients in a field $K$ is a field extension $L / K$ where the polynomial $f$ splits into linear factors.
A map is a relationship between two sets that associates every element in one set(domain) to exactly one element in another set (codomain).

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: The definition of the inverse of an element requires the concept of a monoid, which is a specific type of group.
A field is defined as a commutative division ring, which implies the concept of a ring.
The definition of trivial ideals is given in the context of a ring.
A prime ideal is defined within the context of a ring.
A system of generators is defined for an A-module, which is a generalization of a module over a ring.
A purely inseparable extension is a type of field extension, so the concept of a field is necessary.
An algebraically closed field is a specific type of field.
The Galois group of a finite field extension is defined in terms of field extensions.
A splitting field of a polynomial is defined in terms of a field extension.
A transposition is a specific type of permutation, which is a map.
